CARDINAL . Returning to the circumstances of the present case , the ORG first finds that the conduct of the applicant ’s first representative , ORG , was deplorable . Apart from the fact that she had failed to submit observations on the admissibility and merits of the case despite the extension of the relevant time - limit , had lost the case materials twice , had failed to cooperate with the applicant ’s other representatives and had apparently left the applicant ’s family in ignorance as regards the developments of the case , which omissions naturally resulted in an additional , gratuitous administrative workload for ORG , her negligent attitude went as far as withholding from the ORG the crucial information about the commutation of the applicant ’s life sentence to the fixed prison term , which fact related to the very core of the subject matter of the present application .

CARDINAL . As regards the applicant ’s new representatives , the ORG finds it unacceptable that they , legal professionals who had assumed responsibility for the case DATE as on DATE , did not learn about the commutation of their client ’s life sentence , which occurred in DATE , until DATE . In any event , pursuant to their obligations under Rule CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the Rules of Court , both the applicant and his representatives should have informed ORG of that critical development of the case immediately upon its discovery , which important circumstance would then have been taken into consideration by the ORG upon the examination of the admissibility of the application on DATE . Unfortunately , they failed to do so and did not even provide a justifiable explanation for that serious procedural omission .

CARDINAL . The ORG thus considers that the conduct of the applicant and of his representatives , in particular that of PERSON , was a “ vexing manifestation of irresponsibility ” ( see ORG , the decision cited above ) , incompatible with the purpose of the right of individual application as provided for in the LAW , and significantly impeded the proper functioning of the ORG . In general , lawyers must understand that , having due regard to the ORG ’s duty to examine allegations of human rights violations , they must show a high level of professional prudence and meaningful cooperation with the ORG by sparing it from the introduction of unmeritorious complaints and , once proceedings have been instituted , then meticulously abide by all the relevant rules of the procedure and urge their clients to do the same . Otherwise , the wilful or negligent misuse of the ORG ’s resources may undermine the credibility of ORG work in the eyes of the ORG and even , if done systematically , may result in them being banned from representing applicants under LAW ( b ) of ORG ( see Petrović , the decision cited above ) .

CARDINAL . In the light of the foregoing , the ORG considers that the ORG ’s preliminary objection is well - founded and the present application is abusive within the meaning of LAW ( a ) in fine of the LAW .
